issues.description: The problem statement (UML) and the solution expect Stock.findStockIngredient(String) with a single String parameter, but the template's Stock class declares findStockIngredient(String, boolean) (a two-parameter signature) while other methods in the template (add, take) call findStockIngredient(...) with only one argument. This creates a signature mismatch and a compile-time error in the template, and contradicts the UML/specification. Students will be blocked or confused because the template does not provide the expected single-parameter method and the existing calls in the template are inconsistent with the declared signature.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template's Stock.findStockIngredient signature match the specification/solution by providing a single-parameter method: public StockIngredient findStockIngredient(String name). Either replace the two-parameter method with the single-parameter version, or add an overloaded single-parameter method that delegates to the two-parameter one (e.g., findStockIngredient(String name) calls findStockIngredient(name, true)). Ensure the template's add/take methods call the available single-parameter method to avoid compilation errors.

issues.description: The problem statement's UML specifies Stock.findStockIngredient(String): StockIngredient (single-argument). In the template repository, Stock defines findStockIngredient(String name, boolean caseSensitive) (two-argument), while the provided Main comments (in the template) call findStockIngredient with a single String argument. The solution repository uses the single-argument signature. This mismatch in the method signature across artifacts (problem statement ↔ template ↔ solution) can confuse students about which method to call and what parameters are required.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Stock.findStockIngredient API consistent across artifacts. Either (a) change the template Stock.findStockIngredient to the single-argument signature (findStockIngredient(String name)) to match the UML and solution, or (b) add a one-argument overload in the template that delegates to the two-argument method (e.g., findStockIngredient(String name) { return findStockIngredient(name, true); }). Also update the problem statement or Main comments if you intend the caseSensitive variant to be the canonical API.
